description.text: The Camino Invierno (Winter Way) is a Camino that runs from Ponferrada to Santiago de Compostella, somewhat to the South of the French Way. It then joins the Vía de la Plata and approaches Santiago de Compostella from the South. Traditionally, pilgrims used this way to avoid the snows of O Cebreiro in wintertime, from which its name derives.@en

notes.text: The Winter Way became an official Jacobian way in 2016.@en

There are long stretches without accommodation and, often, without food or drink. Pilgrims need to be fit and prepared to carry food and water. Water fountains have been marked but may not be reliable.@en

description.text: A 'tunnel' dug into the rocky soil, associated with Roman gold-mining

accommodation.name: Los Telaeres del Bierzo Country Lodge

name: Centro de Recepción de Visitantes de Las Médulas@es
Las Médulas Vistor Centre@en

description.text: A UNESCO World Heritage Site. The landscape was formed by Roman gold mining activities.

notes: Pilgrim stamps can be obtained at a casa do teléfono

description.text: With the exception of the drinks available at the pilgrim support point in Albaredos, there is no food or drink and scant accommodation until Quiroga, 27km away.
A corner maintained by two residents, who leave out coffee, tea and juice for pilgrims.

notes.text: Monforte de Lemos is the start point if you wish to travel the 100km to gain your Compostella. It is 132km to Santiago de Compostella. A passport can be obtained from the pilgrim's office.@en

name: Fonte e Área Descanso de Piñeiro@es
Rest Area and Fountain@en

description.text: A small chapel honouring souls that await in purgatory. The 'peto' alms box allows the faithful to fund masses to help them get to heaven.
The Taberna do Peto is the only source of food and drink until Río, 15km away.

name: Ermida do Faro@es
Hermitage of Our Lady of Faro@en

description.text: A pilgrimage site in itself, considered to be at the centre of Galicia@en
A fountain credited with healing powers@en

notes.text: This fountain does not have potable drinking water@en

notes: Pilgrims may enter the premises to spend the night once all activities are over@en

description.text: Lalín stands more or less one hour from all the major cities in Galicia. The location is marked by a plaque in the road.@en

accommodation.name: Hotel and Spa Torre do Deza

name: Merging of the Camino Invierno and the Vía de la Plata@en

description.text: Built in 912, part of the royal roadway connecting Santiago and Ourense
Legend has it that any pilgrim passing this church must tap the door with their head.@en

accommodation.name: Remanso de Transfontao Casa do Compo

description.text: An alternative to climbing Monte Faro and visiting the Hermitage of Nuestra Señora de Faro pilgrimage site at the summit. This route goes North and follows the pass towards Río.@en
notes: This bypass is recommended in Winter, since the peak of Monte Faro at 1138m@en

route-logic.description: Changes for the Monte Faro bypass
